identified-content.classifier: Workfare and Employment of Welfare Recipients

abstract.p: Letter by Kristen Shook and others from University of Chicago says August 24 article on Wisconsin Works program perpetuates 'stereotype' of lazy welfare recipient (S)

block.p: DeParle's article on welfare reform in Wisconsin perpetuates the inaccurate stereotype of the lazy welfare recipient who does not want to work.
DeParle's article on welfare reform in Wisconsin perpetuates the inaccurate stereotype of the lazy welfare recipient who does not want to work.

We interviewed 145 individuals from a representative sampling of Chicago welfare recipients and found that 60 percent had worked in one or more jobs during the past two years, and an additional 20 percent had unsuccessfully looked for work during this time period. The remaining 20 percent neither worked nor looked for work, primarily because of poor health or unmet child-care needs. We spoke with only three individuals who ''just didn't want to work'' and who had no identifiable barriers to employment.

The vast majority express a strong desire to work but are discouraged by the lack of ''livable wage'' jobs. Articles like DeParle's only garner support for more restrictive welfare policies that may have harmful consequences for families trying hard to get off and stay off welfare.
Kristen Shook, Ann Rosenthal, Mona Dugo,
Research Project University of Chicago Chicago
